top_categories.workout_context: Leadville Trail 100 MTB’s mixed mountain terrain—singletrack, fire roads, pavement and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
At 100 miles, Leadville Trail 100 MTB punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Leadville Trail 100 MTB’s singletrack, gravel roads demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Leadville Trail 100 MTB isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Leadville Trail 100 MTB rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Leadville Trail 100 MTB when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Every session at Leadville Trail 100 MTB intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Leadville Trail 100 MTB — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Leadville Trail 100 MTB’s 11,900ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Leadville Trail 100 MTB. Make this intensity feel like home.

Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Leadville Trail 100 MTB — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on mixed mountain terrain—singletrack, fire roads, pavement.
At 100 miles, Leadville Trail 100 MTB rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.

race_overlay.heat: August in Leadville, Colorado can bring heat. Complete 3–4 heat exposure sessions in the final 2 weeks before Leadville Trail 100 MTB. Increase sodium intake 48 hours before race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Leadville Trail 100 MTB’s 100 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.altitude: Leadville Trail 100 MTB with 11,900ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Starts at 10,200 feet elevation; Columbine summit at 12,600 feet.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Leadville Trail 100 MTB demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride mixed mountain terrain—singletrack, fire roads, pavement at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: singletrack, gravel roads, paved sections. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 100 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on VO2max, Durability, and Gravel Specific to prepare you for 100 miles of mixed mountain terrain—singletrack, fire roads, pavement in Leadville, Colorado.
